Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of First Pass Effect in Mechanical Thrombectomy: ASTER Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The ASTER trial was a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint trial conducted from October 2015 to October 2016.

Participants.evidence: Adults with anterior circulation ischemic stroke within 6 hours of onset were randomized to SR (n=189) or CA (n=192).

Intervention.evidence: comparing stent retriever (SR) and contact aspiration (CA) techniques.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses FPE rates and outcomes in the ASTER trial comparing stent retriever (SR) and contact aspiration (CA) techniques.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was favorable clinical outcome (mRS 0-2) at 90 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was stratified by intravenous thrombolysis use, and angiographic outcomes were assessed by a blinded core laboratory.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Adults with anterior circulation ischemic stroke within 6 hours of onset were randomized to SR (n=189) or CA (n=192).

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis included 336 patients using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: FPE was achieved in 97 of 336 patients (28.9%), with no significant difference between SR (31.3%) and CA (26.3%) (adjusted RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.54 to 1.31; p=0.44).

Harms.evidence: FPE also resulted in fewer hemorrhagic transformations (adjusted RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.71 to 1.00) and procedural complications (adjusted RR 0.51, 95% CI 0.26 to 0.99).
